summary: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] is an American politician and former law professor who is the senior United States senator from Massachusetts, serving since 2013. A member of the Democratic Party and regarded as a progressive, [0] has focused on consumer protection, equitable economic opportunity, and the social safety net while in the Senate. [0] was a candidate in the 2020 Democratic Party presidential primaries, ultimately finishing third.Born and raised in Oklahoma, [0] is a graduate of the University of Houston and Rutgers Law School and has taught law at several universities, including the University of Houston, the University of Texas at Austin, the University of Pennsylvania, and Harvard University. [0] was one of the most influential professors in commercial and bankruptcy law before beginning [0]'s political career. [0] has written 12 books and more than 100 articles.[0]'s first foray into public policy began in 1995, when [0] worked to oppose what eventually became a 2005 act restricting bankruptcy access for individuals. During the late 2000s, [0]'s national profile grew after [0]'s forceful public stances in favor of more stringent banking regulations after the financial crisis of 2007–2008. [0] served as chair of the Congressional Oversight Panel of the Troubled Asset Relief Program, and proposed and established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, for which [0] served as the first special advisor under President Barack Obama.In 2012, [0] defeated incumbent Republican Scott Brown and became the first female U.S. senator from Massachusetts. [0] won re-election by a wide margin in 2018, defeating Republican nominee Geoff Diehl. On February 9, 2019, [0] announced [0]'s candidacy in the 2020 United States presidential election. [0] was briefly considered the front-runner for the Democratic nomination in late 2019, but support for [0]'s campaign dwindled. [0] withdrew from the 2020 United States presidential election on March 5, 2020, after Super Tuesday.

Early life and education: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was born [0] in Oklahoma City on June 22, 1949. [0] is the fourth child of Pauline Louise (née Reed, 1912–1995), a homemaker, and Donald Jones Herring (1911–1997), a U.S. Army flight instructor during World War II, both of whom were members of the evangelical branch of the Protestant Methodist Church. [0] has described [0]'s early family life as teetering "on the ragged edge of the middle class" and "kind of hanging on at the edges by our fingernails." [0] and [0]'s three older brothers were raised Methodist.[0] lived in Norman, Oklahoma City, until [0] was 11 years old, when her family moved back to Oklahoma City. When [0] was 12, Donald Jones Herring (1911–1997), a U.S. Army flight instructor during World War II had a heart attack, which led to many medical bills as well as a pay cut because Donald Jones Herring (1911–1997), a U.S. Army flight instructor during World War II could not do Donald Jones Herring (1911–1997), a U.S. Army flight instructor during World War II's previous work. After leaving Donald Jones Herring (1911–1997), a U.S. Army flight instructor during World War II's sales job, Donald Jones Herring (1911–1997), a U.S. Army flight instructor during World War II worked as a maintenance man for an apartment building. Eventually, her family's car was repossessed because her family failed to make loan payments. To help the family finances, [0]'s mother found work in the catalog-order department at Sears. When [0] was 13, [0] started waiting tables at [0]'s aunt's restaurant.[0] became a star member of the debate team at Northwest Classen High School and won the state high school debating championship. [0] also won a debate scholarship to George Washington University (GWU) at the age of 16. [0] initially aspired to be a teacher, but left George Washington University (GWU) after two years in 1968 to marry James Robert "Jim" Warren, whom she had met in high school.Warren and her husband James Robert "Jim" Warren, whom she had met in high school moved to Houston, where James Robert "Jim" Warren, whom she had met in high school was employed by IBM. [0] enrolled in the University of Houston and graduated in 1970 with a Bachelor of Science degree in speech pathology and audiology.Warren and her husband moved to New Jersey when James Robert "Jim" Warren, whom she had met in high school received a job transfer. [0] soon became pregnant and decided to stay at home to care for their daughter, Amelia. After their daughter, Amelia turned two, [0] enrolled at Rutgers Law School. [0] received [0]'s Juris Doctor in 1976 and passed the bar examination shortly thereafter. Shortly before graduating, [0] became pregnant with Warren and her husband's second child, Alexander.

Career: [0] is our person to focus on. In 1970, after obtaining a degree in speech pathology and audiology, but before enrolling in law school, [0] taught children with disabilities for a year in a public school. During law school, [0] worked as a summer associate at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. After receiving [0]'s Juris Doctor and passing the bar examination, [0] offered legal services from home, writing wills and doing real estate closings.In the late 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s, [0] taught law at several American universities while researching issues related to bankruptcy and middle-class personal finance. [0] became involved with public work in bankruptcy regulation and consumer protection in the mid-1990s.
Career.Academic: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] began [0]'s career in academia as a lecturer at Rutgers University, Newark School of Law (1977–1978). [0] then moved to the University of Houston Law Center (1978–1983), where [0] became an associate dean in 1980 and obtained tenure in 1981. [0] taught at the University of Texas School of Law as visiting associate professor in 1981 and returned as a full professor two years later (staying from 1983 to 1987). [0] was a research associate at the Population Research Center of the University of Texas School of Law at Austin from 1983 to 1987 and was also a visiting professor at the University of Michigan in 1985. During this period, [0] also taught Sunday school.[0]'s earliest academic work was heavily influenced by the law and economics movement, which aimed to apply neoclassical economic theory to the study of law with an emphasis on economic efficiency. One of [0]'s articles, published in 1980 in the Notre Dame Law Review, argued that public utilities were over-regulated and that automatic utility rate increases should be instituted. But [0] soon became a proponent of on-the-ground research into how people respond to laws. Her work analyzing court records and interviewing judges, lawyers, and debtors, established [0] as a rising star in the field of bankruptcy law. According to [0] and economists who follow [0]'s work, one of [0]'s key insights was that rising bankruptcy rates were caused not by profligate consumer spending but by middle-class families' attempts to buy homes in good school districts. [0] worked in the field of bankruptcy law alongside colleagues Teresa A. Sullivan and Jay Westbrook, and colleagues Teresa A. Sullivan and Jay Westbrook published colleagues Teresa A. Sullivan and Jay Westbrook's research in the book As We Forgive Our Debtors in 1989. [0] later recalled that [0] had begun Her work analyzing court records and interviewing judges, lawyers, and debtors believing that most people filing for bankruptcy were either working the system or had been irresponsible in incurring debts, but that [0] concluded that such abuse was in fact rare and that the legal framework for bankruptcy was poorly designed, describing the way Her work analyzing court records and interviewing judges, lawyers, and debtors challenged [0]'s fundamental beliefs as "worse than disillusionment" and "like being shocked at a deep-down level". In 2004, [0] published an article in the Washington University Law Review in which [0] argued that correlating middle-class struggles with over-consumption was a fallacy.[0] joined the University of Pennsylvania Law School as a full professor in 1987 and obtained an endowed chair in 1990, becoming the William A. Schnader Professor of Commercial Law. In 1992, [0] taught for a year at Harvard Law School as the Robert Braucher Visiting Professor of Commercial Law. In 1995, [0] left the University of Pennsylvania Law School to become Leo Gottlieb Professor of Law at Harvard Law School. In 1996, [0] became the highest-paid professor at Harvard University who was not an administrator, with a $181,300 salary and total compensation of $291,876, including moving expenses and an allowance in lieu of benefits contributions. As of 2011[update], [0] was Harvard University's only tenured law professor who had attended law school at an American public university. [0] was a highly influential law professor. [0] published in many fields, but [0]'s expertise was in bankruptcy and commercial law. From 2005 to 2009, [0] was among the three most-cited scholars in bankruptcy and commercial law.[0] began to rise in prominence in 2004 with an appearance on the Dr. Phil show, and published several books including The Two-Income Trap.
Career.Advisory roles: [0] is our person to focus on. In 1995, the National Bankruptcy Review Commission's chair, former congressman Mike Synar, asked [0] to advise the National Bankruptcy Review Commission's. the National Bankruptcy Review Commission's chair, former congressman Mike Synar, had been a debate opponent of [0]'s during their school years. [0] helped draft the National Bankruptcy Review Commission's's report and worked for several years to oppose legislation intended to severely restrict consumers' right to file for bankruptcy. [0] and others opposing legislation intended to severely restrict consumers' right to file for bankruptcy were not successful; in 2005, Congress passed the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act of 2005, which curtailed consumers' ability to file for bankruptcy.From 2006 to 2010, [0] was a member of the FDIC (Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation) Advisory Committee on Economic Inclusion. [0] is a member of the National Bankruptcy Conference, an independent organization that advises Congress on bankruptcy law, a former vice president of the American Law Institute and a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.[0]'s scholarship and public advocacy were the impetus for establishing the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in 2011.: 1315
Career.TARP oversight: [0] is our person to focus on. On November 14, 2008, U.S. Senate majority leader Harry Reid appointed [0] to chair the five-member Congressional Oversight Panel created to oversee the implementation of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act. the five-member Congressional Oversight Panel created to oversee the implementation of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act released monthly oversight reports evaluating the government bailout and related programs. During [0]'s tenure, monthly oversight reports evaluating the government bailout and related programs covered foreclosure mitigation, consumer and small business lending, commercial real estate, AIG, bank stress tests, the impact of the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) on the financial markets, government guarantees, the automotive industry and other topics.
Career.Consumer Financial Protection Bureau: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was an early advocate for creating a new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB). a new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) was established by the Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, signed into law by President Obama in July 2010. In September 2010, President Obama named [0] Assistant to the President and Special Advisor to the Secretary of the Treasury on a new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) to set up a new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB). While liberal groups and consumer advocacy groups urged President Obama to formally nominate [0] as a new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)'s director, financial institutions and Republican members of Congress strongly opposed [0], believing [0] would be an overly zealous regulator. Reportedly convinced that [0] could not win Senate confirmation as a new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)'s , in January 2012, President Obama appointed former Ohio attorney general Richard Cordray to the bureau's first director in a recess appointment over Republican senators' objections.
Career.Political affiliation: [0] is our person to focus on. A close high-school friend told Politico in 2019 that in high school [0] was a "diehard conservative" and that [0] had since done a "180-degree turn and an about-face". One of [0]'s colleagues at the University of Texas in Austin said that at university in the early 1980s [0] was "sometimes surprisingly anti-consumer in [0]'s attitude". Gary L. Francione, who had been a colleague of hers at the University of Pennsylvania, recalled in 2019 that when Gary L. Francione, who had been a colleague of hers at the University of Pennsylvania, heard [0] speak at the time [0] was becoming politically prominent, Gary L. Francione, who had been a colleague of hers at the University of Pennsylvania, "almost fell off [Gary L. Francione, who had been a colleague of hers at the University of Pennsylvania,'s] chair... [0]'s definitely changed". [0] was registered as a Republican from 1991 to 1996 and voted Republican for many years. "[0] was a Republican because [0] thought that Republican were the people who best supported markets", [0] has said. But [0] has also said that in the six presidential elections before 1996 [0] voted for the Republican nominee only once, in 1976, for Gerald Ford.[0] has said that [0] began to vote Democratic in 1995 because [0] no longer believed that Republican were the party who best supported markets, but [0] has said [0] has voted for both parties because [0] believed neither should dominate. According to [0], [0] left Republican because Republican is no longer "principled in Republican's conservative approach to economics and to markets" and is instead tilting the playing field in favor of large financial institutions and against middle-class American families.

U.S. Senate (2013\u2013present).Elections: [0] is our person to focus on. On September 14, 2011, [0] declared [0]'s intention to run for the Democratic nomination for the 2012 election in Massachusetts for the U.S. Senate. Republican Scott Brown had won the U.S. Senate in a 2010 special election after Ted Kennedy's death. A week later, a video of Warren speaking in Andover went viral on the Internet. In a video of Warren speaking in Andover, [0] responds to the charge that asking the rich to pay more taxes is "class warfare" by saying that no one grew rich in the U.S. without depending on infrastructure paid for by the rest of society:There is nobody in this country who got rich on his ownnobody in this country who got rich on his own's . Nobody. ... You moved your goods to market on the roads the rest of society paid for; you hired workers the rest of society paid to educate; you were safe in your factory because of police forces and fire forces that the rest of society paid for. You didn't have to worry that marauding bands would come and seize everything at your factory, and hire someone to protect against this, because of the work the rest of society did. Now look, you built a factory and a factory turned into something terrific, or a great idea. God bless. Keep a big hunk of it. But part of the underlying social contract is, you take a hunk of that and pay forward for the next kid who comes along. President Obama later echoed [0]'s sentiments in a the 2012 election campaign speech.[0] ran unopposed for the Democratic nomination for the 2012 election in Massachusetts for the U.S. Senate and won the Democratic nomination for the 2012 election in Massachusetts for the U.S. Senate on June 2, 2012, at the state Democratic convention with a record 95.77% of the votes of delegates. [0] encountered significant opposition from business interests. In August, the political director for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce commented that "no other candidate in 2012 represents a greater threat to free enterprise than [0]". [0] nonetheless raised $39 million for [0]'s campaign, more than any other the U.S. Senate candidate in 2012, and showed, according to The New York Times, "that it was possible to run against the big banks without Wall Street money and still win".[0] received a prime-time speaking slot at the 2012 Democratic National Convention on September 5, 2012. [0] positioned [0] as a champion of a beleaguered middle class that "has been chipped, squeezed, and hammered". According to [0], "People feel like the system is rigged against People. And here's the painful part: People're right. the system is rigged." [0] said Wall Street CEOs "wrecked our economy and destroyed millions of jobs" and that Wall Street CEOs "still strut around congress, no shame, demanding favors, and acting like we should thank them".On January 6, 2017, in an email to supporters, [0] announced that [0] would be running for a second term as a U.S. senator from Massachusetts, writing, "The people of Massachusetts didn't send [0] to Washington to roll over and play dead while Donald Trump and Donald Trump's team of billionaires, bigots, and Wall Street bankers crush the working people of the U.S. and the U.S.. ... This is no time to quit."In the 2018 election, [0] defeated Republican nominee Geoff Diehl, 60% to 36%.
U.S. Senate (2013\u2013present).Tenure: [0] is our person to focus on. On November 6, 2012, [0] defeated Brown with 53.7% of the vote. [0] is the first woman ever elected to the U.S. Senate from Massachusetts, as part of a sitting U.S. Senate that had 20 women senators in office, which was the most in the U.S. Senate history at the time, following the November 2012 elections. In December 2012, [0] was assigned a seat on the Senate Banking Committee, which oversees the implementation of Dodd–Frank and other regulation of the banking industry. Vice President Joe Biden swore [0] in on January 3, 2013.At [0]'s first the Senate Banking Committee, which oversees the implementation of Dodd–Frank and other regulation of the banking industry hearing in February 2013, [0] pressed several banking regulators to say when several banking regulators had last taken a Wall Street bank to trial and said, "[0]'m really concerned that 'too big to fail' has become 'too big for trial'." Videos of [0]'s questioning amassed more than one million views in a matter of days. At a March Banking Committee hearing, [0] asked Treasury Department officials why criminal charges were not brought against HSBC for HSBC's money laundering practices. [0] compared money laundering to drug possession, saying: "If you're caught with an ounce of cocaine, the chances are good you're going to go to jail ... But evidently, if you launder nearly a billion dollars for drug cartels and violate our international sanctions, your company pays a fine and you go home and sleep in your own bed at night."In May 2013, [0] sent letters to the Justice Department, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Federal Reserve questioning the Justice Department, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Federal Reserve's decisions that settling would be more fruitful than going to court. Also in May 2013, saying that students should get "the same great deal that banks get", [0] introduced the Bank on Student Loans Fairness Act, which would allow students to take out government education loans at the same rate that banks pay to borrow from the federal government, 0.75%. Independent senator Bernie Sanders endorsed her bill, saying: "The only thing wrong with her bill is that [[0]] thought of her bill and Independent senator Bernie Sanders didn't".During the 2014 election cycle, [0] was a top Democratic fundraiser. After the November 2012 elections, [0] was appointed to become the first-ever Strategic Adviser of the Democratic Policy and Communications Committee, a position created for [0]. appointed added to speculation that [0] would run for president in 2016.In early 2015, President Obama urged Congress to approve the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a proposed free trade agreement between the United States and 11 Asian and South American countries. [0] criticized the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a proposed free trade agreement between the United States and 11 Asian and South American countries, arguing that the dispute resolution mechanism in the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a proposed free trade agreement between the United States and 11 Asian and South American countries and labor protections for American workers therein were insufficient; [0]'s objections were in turn criticized by President Obama.Saying "despite the progress we've made since 2008, the biggest banks continue to threaten we's economy", in July 2015 [0], John McCain, Maria Cantwell, and Angus King reintroduced the 21st Century Glass–Steagall Act, a modern version of the Banking Act of 1933. the 21st Century Glass–Steagall Act, a modern version of the Banking Act of 1933 was intended to reduce the American taxpayer's risk in the financial system and the likelihood of future financial crises.In a September 20, 2016, hearing, [0] called on Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf to resign, adding that Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf should be "criminally investigated" over Wells Fargo's opening of two million checking and credit-card accounts without the customers' consent.In December 2016, [0] gained a seat on the Senate Armed Services Committee, which The Boston Globe called "a high-profile perch on one of the U.S. Senate's most powerful committees" that would "fuel speculation about a possible 2020 bid for president".During the debate on Senator Jeff Sessions's nomination for United States attorney general in February 2017, [0] quoted a letter Coretta Scott King had written Senator Strom Thurmond in 1986 when Sessions was nominated for a federal judgeship. Coretta Scott King wrote, "Senator Jeff Sessions's has used the awesome power of Senator Jeff Sessions's's office to chill the free exercise of the vote by black citizens in the district Senator Jeff Sessions's now seeks to serve as a federal judge. This simply cannot be allowed to happen." Senate Republicans voted that by reading a letter Coretta Scott King had written Senator Strom Thurmond in 1986 when Sessions was nominated for a federal judgeship, [0] had violated Senate Rule 19, which prohibits impugning another senator's character. Senate Rule 19, which prohibits impugning another senator's character prohibited [0] from further participating in the debate on Senator Jeff Sessions's nomination for United States attorney general in February 2017, and [0] instead read a letter Coretta Scott King had written Senator Strom Thurmond in 1986 when Sessions was nominated for a federal judgeship while streaming live online. In rebuking [0], Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on the Senate floor, "[0] was warned. [0] was given an explanation. Nevertheless, [0] persisted." Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's language became a slogan for [0] and others.On October 3, 2017, during Wells Fargo chief executive Timothy J. Sloan's's appearance before the Senate Banking Committee, [0] called on Wells Fargo chief executive Timothy J. Sloan's to resign, saying, "At best Wells Fargo chief executive Timothy J. Sloan's were incompetent, at worst Wells Fargo chief executive Timothy J. Sloan's were complicit."On July 17, 2019, [0] and Representative Al Lawson introduced legislation that would make low-income college students eligible for benefits under the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) according to the College Student Hunger Act of 2019.In November 2020, [0] was named a candidate for Secretary of the Treasury in the Vice President Joe Biden Administration.[0] was at the Capitol to participate in the 2021 United States Electoral College vote count when Trump supporters attacked the Capitol. [0] called attacked an "attempted coup and act of insurrection egged on by Trump to overthrow we's democracy", and the perpetrators "domestic terrorists." The day after attacked, [0] joined the entire Massachusetts Congressional delegation to call for Trump's immediate removal from office through the invocation of the Twenty-fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution or impeachment.
U.S. Senate (2013\u2013present).Role in the 2016 presidential election: [0] is our person to focus on. In the run-up to the 2016 United States presidential election, supporters put [0] forward as a possible presidential candidate, but [0] repeatedly said [0] would not run for president in the 2016 United States presidential election. In October 2013, [0] joined the other 15 women Democratic senators in signing a letter that encouraged Hillary Clinton to run. There was much speculation about [0] being added to the Democratic ticket as a vice-presidential candidate. On June 9, the 2016 United States presidential election, after the California Democratic primary, [0] formally endorsed Hillary Clinton for president. In response to questions when [0] endorsed Hillary Clinton, [0] said that [0] believed [0] to be ready to be vice president, but [0] was not being vetted. On July 7, CNN reported that [0] was on a five-person short list to be Hillary Clinton's running mate. Hillary Clinton eventually chose Tim Kaine.Until [0]'s June , [0] was neutral during the California Democratic primary but made public statements that [0] was cheering Bernie Sanders on. In June, [0] endorsed and campaigned for Hillary Clinton. [0] called Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee, dishonest, uncaring, and "a loser".

2020 presidential campaign: [0] is our person to focus on. At a town hall meeting in Holyoke, Massachusetts, on September 29, 2018, [0] said [0] would "take a hard look" at running for president in the 2020 election after the 2018 United States elections concluded. On December 31, 2018, [0] announced that [0] was forming an exploratory committee to run for president.On February 9, 2019, [0] officially announced [0]'s candidacy at a rally in Lawrence, Massachusetts, at the site of the 1912 Bread and Roses strike. A longtime critic of President Trump, [0] called President Trump a "symptom of a larger problem [that has resulted in] a rigged system that props up the rich and powerful and kicks dirt on everyone else".[0] staged [0]'s first campaign event in Lawrence, Massachusetts to demonstrate the constituency groups [0] hopes to appeal to, including working class families, union members, women, and new immigrants. [0] called for major changes in government:It won't be enough to just undo the terrible acts of this administration. We can't afford to just tinker around the edges—a tax credit here, a regulation there. Our fight is for big, structural change. Our fight is the fight of our lives. The fight to build an America where dreams are possible, an America that works for everyone. Following [0]'s , [0] became known for the number and depth of [0]'s policy proposals, including plans to assist family farms by addressing the advantages held by large agricultural conglomerates, plans to reduce student loan debt and offer free tuition at public colleges, a plan to make large corporations pay more in taxes and better regulate large technology companies, several proposals inspired by opposition to President Trump, a plan to utilize economic patriotism, and plans to address opioid addiction. One of [0]'s signature plans was a wealth tax, dubbed the "Ultra-Millionaire Tax", on fortunes over $50 million. [0] was credited with popularizing the idea of a wealth tax with Americans, leading competitor Bernie Sanders to release a wealth tax plan.After several defeats at the polls, including the Democratic primary in [0]'s , [0] ended [0]'s campaign on March 5, 2020.
2020 presidential campaign.Polls: [0] is our person to focus on. In early June 2019, [0] placed second in some polls, with Joe Biden in first place and Bernie Sanders in third. In the following weeks [0]'s poll numbers steadily increased, and a September Iowa poll placed [0] in the lead with 22% to Joe Biden's 20%. a September Iowa poll also rated the number of voters at least considering voting for each candidate; [0] scored 71% to Joe Biden's 60%. Poll respondents also gave [0] a higher "enthusiasm" rating, with 32% of [0]'s backers extremely enthusiastic to Joe Biden's 22%.An October 24 Quinnipiac poll placed [0] in the lead at 28%, with Joe Biden at 21% and Bernie Sanders at 15%. When asked which candidate had the best policy ideas, 30% of respondents named [0], with Bernie Sanders at 20% and Joe Biden 15%. Bernie Sanders was most often named as the candidate who "cares most about people like you," with [0] in second place and Joe Biden third. Bernie Sanders also placed first at 28% when respondents were asked which candidate was the most honest, followed by [0] and Joe Biden at 15% each.
2020 presidential campaign.Funding: [0] is our person to focus on. The Los Angeles Times reported that of the front-runners in the presidential race, only Sanders and [0] have previously won an election with almost exclusively small online contributions, and that no presidential primary in recent history has had two of the front-runners in the presidential race refuse to use bundlers or hold private fundraisers with wealthy donors.In January 2019, [0] said that [0] took no PAC money. In October 2019, [0] announced that her campaign would not accept contributions of more than $200 from executives at banks, large tech companies, private equity firms, or hedge funds, in addition to [0]'s previous refusal to accept donations of over $200 from fossil fuel or pharmaceutical executives.In the third quarter of 2019, her campaign raised $24.6 million, just less than the $25.3 million Sanders's campaign raised and well ahead of Joe Biden, the front-runner in the polls, who raised $15.2 million. [0]'s average donation was $26; Sanders's was $18.In February 2020, [0] began accepting support from Super PACs, after failing to convince other Democratic presidential candidates to join [0] in disavowing Super PACs.
2020 presidential campaign.Public appearances: [0] is our person to focus on. As of September 2019, [0] had attended 128 town halls. [0] is known for remaining afterward to talk with audience members and for the large numbers of selfies [0] has taken with audience members. On September 17, over 20,000 people attended a [0] rally at New York City's Washington Square Park. After [0]'s speech long lines formed with people waiting as long as four hours for selfies.Due to the impeachment trial of Donald Trump, [0] was unable to make final campaign stops in person and opted to send [0]'s dog, Bailey Warren, to meet with voters in Iowa.
2020 presidential campaign.Vice-presidential speculation: [0] is our person to focus on. In June 2020, CNN reported that [0] was among the top four vice-presidential choices for Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, along with Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms, Representative Val Demings, and Senator Kamala Harris. Senator Kamala Harris was officially announced as Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee's running mate on August 11, 2020. On August 13, The New York Times reported that [0] was one of Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee's four finalists along with Senator Kamala Harris, Susan Rice, and Gretchen Whitmer.In late April, CNBC reported that big-money donors were pressuring Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee not to choose [0], preferring other candidates purportedly on Joe Biden, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee's list, such as Senator Kamala Harris, Gretchen Whitmer, and Amy Klobuchar.

Personal life: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] and her first husband divorced in 1978, and two years later, [0] married law professor Bruce H. Mann on July 12, 1980, but kept her first husband's surname. [0] has three grandchildren through [0]'s daughter Amelia.On April 23, 2020, [0] announced on Twitter that [0]'s eldest brother, Don Reed Herring, had died of COVID-19 two days earlier. On October 1, 2021, [0] announced that [0]'s brother, John Herring, had died of cancer.As of 2019, according to Forbes Magazine, [0]'s net worth was $12 million.

Political positions: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] is widely regarded as a progressive. In 2012, the British magazine New Statesman named [0] among the "top 20 U.S. progressives".[0] supports worker representation on corporations' board of directors, breaking up monopolies, stiffening sentences for white-collar crime, a Medicare for All plan to provide health insurance for all Americans, and a higher minimum wage.[0] was highly critical of the Trump administration. [0] expressed concerns over what [0] says were Trump's conflicts of interest. The Presidential Conflicts of Interest Act, written by [0], was first read in the Senate in January 2017. [0] was highly critical of Trump's immigration policies. In 2018, [0] called for abolishing U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).Warren has criticized U.S. involvement in the Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen in support of Yemen's government against the Houthis. In January 2019, [0] criticized Trump's decision to withdraw U.S. troops from Syria and Afghanistan. [0] agreed that U.S. troops should be withdrawn from Syria and Afghanistan but said such withdrawals should be part of a "coordinated" plan formed with U.S. allies.In April 2019, after reading the Mueller report, [0] called on the House of Representatives to begin impeachment proceedings against Trump, saying, "the Mueller report lays out facts showing that a hostile foreign government attacked our 2016 election to help Trump and Trump welcomed help. Once elected, Trump obstructed the investigation into attacked."After the June 24, 2022, ruling in which the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, [0] wrote a New York Times op-ed requesting that President Biden unblock "critical resources and authority that states and the federal government can use to meet the surge in demand for reproductive health services".On March 13, 2023, [0] presented a detailed analysis of the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank on March 10, 2023, and provided possible solutions to avoid further bank failures, in New York Times.

Ancestry and Native American issues: [0] is our person to focus on. According to Warren and her brothers, older family members told Warren and her brothers during Warren and her brothers's childhood that Warren and her brothers had some Native American ancestry. In 2012, [0] said that "being Native American has been part of [0]'s story, [0] guess, since the day [0] was born". In 1984, [0] contributed recipes to a Native American cookbook and identified [0] as Cherokee.During [0]'s first Senate race in 2012, [0]'s opponent, Scott Brown, speculated that [0] had fabricated Native ancestry to gain advantage on the employment market and used [0]'s ancestry in several attack ads. [0] has denied that [0]'s alleged heritage gave [0] any advantages in [0]'s schooling or [0]'s career. Several colleagues and employers (including Harvard) have said her reported ethnic status played no role in [0]'s hiring. Books and other works: [0] is our person to focus on. In 2004, Warren and her daughter, Amelia Tyagi, wrote The Two-Income Trap: Why Middle-Class Mothers and Fathers Are Going Broke. In The Two-Income Trap: Why Middle-Class Mothers and Fathers Are Going Broke Warren and her daughter, Amelia Tyagi, state that at that time, a fully employed worker earned less inflation-adjusted income than a fully employed worker had 30 years earlier. Although families spent less at that time on clothing, appliances, and other forms of consumption, the costs of core expenses such as mortgages, health care, transportation, and child care had increased dramatically. According to Warren and her daughter, Amelia Tyagi,, the result was that even families with two income earners were no longer able to save and incurred ever greater debt.In an article in The New York Times, Jeff Madrick said of The Two-Income Trap: Why Middle-Class Mothers and Fathers Are Going Broke: Warren and her daughter, Amelia Tyagi, find that it is not the free-spending young or the incapacitated elderly who are declaring bankruptcy so much as families with children ... Warren and her daughter, Amelia Tyagi,'s main thesis is undeniable. Typical families often cannot afford the high-quality education, health care, and neighborhoods required to be middle class today. More clearly than anyone else, Jeff Madrick think, Warren and her daughter, Amelia Tyagi, have shown how little attention the nation and our government have paid to the way Americans really live.  In 2005, Warren and David Himmelstein published a study on bankruptcy and medical bills that found that half of all families filing for bankruptcy did so in the aftermath of a serious medical problem. Warren and David Himmelstein say that three-quarters of such families had medical insurance. a study on bankruptcy and medical bills that found that half of all families filing for bankruptcy did so in the aftermath of a serious medical problem was widely cited in policy debates, but some have challenged a study on bankruptcy and medical bills that found that half of all families filing for bankruptcy did so in the aftermath of a serious medical problem's methods and offered alternative interpretations of the data, suggesting that only 17% of bankruptcies are directly attributable to medical expenses.Metropolitan Books published Warren's book A Fighting Chance in April 2014. According to a Boston Globe review, "Warren's book A Fighting Chance's title refers to a time [0] says is now gone, when even families of modest means who worked hard and played by the rules had at a fair shot at the American dream."In April 2017, [0] published [0]'s 11th book, This Fight Is Our Fight: The Battle to Save America's Middle Class, in which [0] explores the plight of America's Middle Class and argues that our government needs to do more to help working families with stronger social programs and increased investment in education.
